Basic Job Description: Stand watch at bow or on wing of bridge to look for obstructions in path of vessel. Measure water depth. Turn wheel on bridge or use emergency equipment as directed by mate. Break out, rig, overhaul, and store cargo-handling gear, stationary rigging, and running gear. Chip rust from and paint deck or ship's structure. Must hold government-issued certification. Must hold certification when working aboard liquid-carrying vessels.
Duties: 1) Measures depth of water in shallow or unfamiliar waters, using leadline, and telephones or shouts information to bridge.2) Breaks out, rigs, overhauls, and stows cargo-handling gear, stationary rigging, and running gear. 3) Stands watch from bow of ship or wing of bridge to look for obstruction in path of ship.4) Steers ship and maintains visual communication with other ships.5) Steers ship under direction of ship's commander or navigating officer, or directs helmsman to steer, following designated course. 6) Overhauls lifeboats and lifeboat gear, and lowers or raises lifeboats with winch or falls.7) Paints and chips rust on deck or superstructure of ship.8) Stands by wheel when ship is on automatic pilot and verifies accuracy of course by comparing with magnetic compass. 9) Gives directions to crew engaged in cleaning wheelhouse and quarter deck.10) Maintains ship's log while in port, and stands gangway watch to prevent unauthorized persons from boarding ship.11) Stows or removes cargo from ship's hold.

Skills: 1) Equipment Selection -- Determining the kind of tools and equipment needed to do a job. 2) Operation Monitoring -- Watching gauges, dials, or other indicators to make sure a machine is working properly.3) Operation and Control -- Controlling operations of equipment or systems.4) Monitoring -- Monitoring/Assessing performance of yourself, other individuals, or organizations to make improvements or take corrective action.5) Coordination -- Adjusting actions in relation to others' actions.
Abilities: 1) Oral Expression -- The ability to communicate information and ideas in speaking so others will understand. 2) Far Vision -- The ability to see details at a distance.3) Control Precision -- The ability to quickly and repeatedly adjust the controls of a machine or a vehicle to exact positions.4) Spatial Orientation -- The ability to know your location in relation to the environment or to know where other objects are in relation to you.5) Oral Comprehension -- The ability to listen to and understand information and ideas presented through spoken words and sentences. 6) Selective Attention -- The ability to concentrate on a task over a period of time without being distracted.7) Arm-Hand Steadiness -- The ability to keep your hand and arm steady while moving your arm or while holding your arm and hand in one position.8) Static Strength -- The ability to exert maximum muscle force to lift, push, pull, or carry objects.9) Speech Clarity -- The ability to speak clearly so others can understand you.
